articles.headline: Even After New Highs, the Rally May Last
articles.snippet: A study of past returns from the Standard & Poor’s 500 suggests that the index’s recent highs should not discourage investors.
articles.abstract: A study of past returns from the Standard & Poor’s 500 suggests that the index’s recent highs should not discourage investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the party over?

articles.headline: A Stubborn Drought Tests Texas Ranchers
articles.snippet: As a three-year drought parches their grazing land, some ranchers are staying afloat on a combination of ingenuity and patience.
articles.abstract: As a three-year drought parches their grazing land, some ranchers are staying afloat on a combination of ingenuity and patience.
articles.lead_paragraph: BLOOMING GROVE, Tex. — Gary Price is a rarity among cattle ranchers these days. He’s making money on his herd of 200 cows in this tiny town about an hour south of Dallas-Fort Worth.

articles.headline: Boeing’s 787 Takes Flight to Assess New Battery
articles.snippet: Almost three months after the airliners were grounded, Boeing moved closer to getting them back in service.
articles.abstract: Almost three months after the airliners were grounded, Boeing moved closer to getting them back in service.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Boeing 787 flew for nearly two hours on Friday in a flight that wrapped up the company’s tests of modifications meant to prevent fires in its lithium-ion batteries.

articles.headline: A Quick Electronic Signature at the Car Rental Office, and Then Trouble
articles.snippet: Some Dollar Rent a Car customers say they unwittingly signed up for insurance even though they had verbally declined it.
articles.abstract: Some Dollar Rent a Car customers say they unwittingly signed up for insurance even though they had verbally declined it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sandra McKinnon knew the drill after three trips from Oakland, Calif., to Tulsa, Okla., to visit her elderly father. When she went to pick up a rental car, she would have to decide whether to buy the insurance.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Works to Avert Split of Chief and Chairman Roles
articles.snippet: In anticipation of a crucial vote at next month’s annual meeting, board members are said to be planning to meet with some of the bank’s biggest shareholders to make their case that JPMorgan’s influential chief executive, Jamie Dimon, should keep h...
articles.abstract: In anticipation of a crucial vote at next month’s annual meeting, board members are said to be planning to meet with some of the bank’s biggest shareholders to make their case that JPMorgan’s influential chief executive, Jamie Dimon, should keep his chairman title.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is working behind the scenes to avert a major potential embarrassment.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Detecting Shift, U.S. Makes Case to China on North Korea
articles.snippet: The Obama administration, seeing signs of Chinese frustration toward Pyongyang, is pressing China to crack down or face more of an American military presence in Asia.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration, seeing signs of Chinese frustration toward Pyongyang, is pressing China to crack down or face more of an American military presence in Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, detecting what it sees as a shift in decades of Chinese support for North Korea, is pressuring China’s new president, Xi Jinping, to crack down on the regime in Pyongyang or face a heightened American military presence in its region.

articles.headline: The Infinity Pool of Executive Pay
articles.snippet: For C.E.O.’s of some of the nation’s biggest companies, overall compensation rose only modestly last year. But the amount of perks often soared.
articles.abstract: For C.E.O.’s of some of the nation’s biggest companies, overall compensation rose only modestly last year. But the amount of perks often soared.
articles.lead_paragraph: RELAX. Sit back. And forget, for a moment, those pesky shareholders and bothersome boards, the regulations, the investigations and all the other headaches of being a chief executive today.

articles.headline: If Shareholders Say ‘Enough Already,’ the Board May Listen
articles.snippet: In many ways, executive pay is continuing  its merry climb. But shareholders and some company boards have made inroads against the trend.
articles.abstract: In many ways, executive pay is continuing  its merry climb. But shareholders and some company boards have made inroads against the trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAISES may be hard-won for most American workers these days, but for those fortunate few in the executive suite, the pay increases just keep on coming. Last year, the median chief executive at a United States company with more than $5 billion in revenue received about $14 million, 2.8 percent more than in 2011, according to an annual pay analysis conducted by Equilar. The 2012 increase, though relatively modest, still represents a raise for most of those who inhabit the corner office (and whose companies had filed the data by the end of March).

articles.headline: A Secret Deal on Drones, Sealed in Blood
articles.snippet: The C.I.A.’s covert drone war in Pakistan began with the 2004 killing of a Pashtun militant, the result of a secret deal that was a turning point in the agency’s fight against terrorism.
articles.abstract: The C.I.A.’s covert drone war in Pakistan began with the 2004 killing of a Pashtun militant, the result of a secret deal that was a turning point in the agency’s fight against terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nek Muhammad knew he was being followed.

articles.headline: Grave Robbers and War Steal Syria’s History
articles.snippet: Syria’s archaeological heritage, which has yet to be fully studied, is imperiled by threats ranging from outright destruction to opportunistic treasure hunters.
articles.abstract: Syria’s archaeological heritage, which has yet to be fully studied, is imperiled by threats ranging from outright destruction to opportunistic treasure hunters.
articles.lead_paragraph: TELL MARDIKH, Syria — Ali Shibleh crawled through a two-foot-high tunnel until reaching a slightly larger subterranean space. He swung his flashlight’s beam into the dark.

articles.headline: Tax Lobby Builds Ties to Chairman of Finance Panel
articles.snippet: Many companies have retained lobbying firms that employ former aides to Max Baucus, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which will have a crucial role in shaping tax legislation.
articles.abstract: Many companies have retained lobbying firms that employ former aides to Max Baucus, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which will have a crucial role in shaping tax legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Restaurant chains like McDonald’s want to keep their lucrative tax credit for hiring veterans. Altria, the tobacco giant, wants to cut the corporate tax rate. And Sapphire Energy, a small alternative energy company, is determined to protect a tax incentive it believes could turn algae into a popular motor fuel.

articles.headline: Taping of Farm Cruelty Is Becoming the Crime
articles.snippet: States are restricting undercover operations by activists in response to exposés that industry groups say have led to unfair scrutiny.
articles.abstract: States are restricting undercover operations by activists in response to exposés that industry groups say have led to unfair scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: On one covert video, farm workers illegally burn the ankles of Tennessee walking horses with chemicals. Another captures workers in Wyoming punching and kicking pigs and flinging piglets into the air. And at one of the country’s largest egg suppliers, a video shows hens caged alongside rotting bird corpses, while workers burn and snap off the beaks of young chicks.

articles.headline: Lilly Pulitzer Dies at 81; Heiress Who Gave Elite Clothes a Tropical Splash
articles.snippet: Ms. Pulitzer, whose tropical print dresses became a fashion classic, got her start in 1959 by spilling orange juice on her clothes.
articles.abstract: Ms. Pulitzer, whose tropical print dresses became a fashion classic, got her start in 1959 by spilling orange juice on her clothes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lilly Pulitzer, the Palm Beach princess of prints who created an enduring fashion uniform for wealthy socialites and jet setters almost by accident, died on Sunday at her home in Florida. She was 81.

articles.headline: With Swagger, Afghan Army Takes the Lead
articles.snippet: On a recent mission, a unit of the Afghan National Army gave some clues to how prepared it was to fight the Taliban after American forces are gone.
articles.abstract: On a recent mission, a unit of the Afghan National Army gave some clues to how prepared it was to fight the Taliban after American forces are gone.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMDARA, Afghanistan — Through the crackle of the hand radio, the Taliban fighter could be heard screaming at his comrades, berating them to strike from their mountain hide-outs and kill the infidel forces gathered nearby.

articles.headline: Lew to Press for European Policy Changes
articles.snippet: In his first trip to Europe as Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew will try to persuade finance ministers of other nations to pursue more growth and less austerity.
articles.abstract: In his first trip to Europe as Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew will try to persuade finance ministers of other nations to pursue more growth and less austerity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jacob J. Lew began his first trip to Europe as Treasury secretary on Sunday, a four-city tour in which he is expected to try to persuade finance ministers to pursue a little more growth and a little less austerity to improve the economic fortunes of the Continent and the world.

articles.headline: New Trouble for Euro in Portugal
articles.snippet: Portugal’s prime minister warned on Sunday that additional spending cuts were needed after a court struck down some austerity measures agreed to for a bailout two years ago.
articles.abstract: Portugal’s prime minister warned on Sunday that additional spending cuts were needed after a court struck down some austerity measures agreed to for a bailout two years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just weeks after European leaders tamped down a banking crisis in Cyprus, troubles in the euro zone have again reared their head, this time in Portugal.

articles.headline: Roger Ebert as a Builder of an Empire
articles.snippet: A big part of what Roger Ebert left behind was a remarkable template for how a lone journalist can become something much more.
articles.abstract: A big part of what Roger Ebert left behind was a remarkable template for how a lone journalist can become something much more.
articles.lead_paragraph: At journalism conferences and online, media strivers talk over and over about becoming their own brand, hoping that some magical combination of tweets, video spots, appearances and, yes, even actual written articles, will help their name come to mean something.

articles.headline: Chief Tries to Infuse Yahoo With a Start-Up’s Spirit
articles.snippet: Notorious for flubbing acquisitions, Yahoo has bought six small companies under Marissa Mayer in an attempt to cultivate innovative engineers and technologies.
articles.abstract: Notorious for flubbing acquisitions, Yahoo has bought six small companies under Marissa Mayer in an attempt to cultivate innovative engineers and technologies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since taking the reins at Yahoo, Marissa Mayer has been trying to convince customers and employees that there is still life in a company that Silicon Valley long ago left for dead.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Sponsors Now Pay for Online Articles, Not Just Ads
articles.snippet: The strategy of advertisers sponsoring or producing content that looks much like traditional editorial content has become increasingly common as publishers try to create more sources of revenue.
articles.abstract: The strategy of advertisers sponsoring or producing content that looks much like traditional editorial content has become increasingly common as publishers try to create more sources of revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Articles in a series on Mashable.com called “What’s Inside” looked for all the world like the hundreds of other articles on the digital media site. But journalistically, they were something very different.

articles.headline: Eye on Ratings, ABC Peers Into the Disney Toy Chest
articles.snippet: ABC had always stood apart from the Disney way, but recently the network has floated a few pilots on concepts drawn from its powerful parent’s library.
articles.abstract: ABC had always stood apart from the Disney way, but recently the network has floated a few pilots on concepts drawn from its powerful parent’s library.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For 17 years, ever since the Walt Disney Company swallowed its corporate parent, ABC has been a type of distant planet in the Disney universe. With nothing overtly Disney-ish about ABC, it has largely operated outside the company’s synergistic approach to show business — theme parks fueling movies fueling merchandise fueling cable channels.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: U.S. Designs a Korea Response Proportional to the Provocation
articles.snippet: American officials said new “counterprovocation” plans called for a response that would hit the source of any attack by North Korea with similar weapons.
articles.abstract: American officials said new “counterprovocation” plans called for a response that would hit the source of any attack by North Korea with similar weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As North Korea hints at new military provocations in the coming days, the United States and South Korea have drawn up plans to respond more forcefully than in the recent past, but in a limited way intended to prevent an escalation to broader war.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Targeted Killing Comes to Define War on Terror
articles.snippet: Despite administration officials’ statements that their strong preference is for capturing terrorists, a reliance on killing terrorism suspects has defined the Obama years.
articles.abstract: Despite administration officials’ statements that their strong preference is for capturing terrorists, a reliance on killing terrorism suspects has defined the Obama years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, was taken into American custody at an airport stopover in Jordan last month, he joined one of the most select groups of the Obama era: high-level terrorist suspects who have been located by the American counterterrorism juggernaut, and who have not been killed.

articles.headline: Obama Must Walk Fine Line as Congress Takes Up Agenda
articles.snippet: President Obama’s second-term priorities — the deficit, gun safety and immigration — may hinge on his ability to inject himself into negotiations to just the right degree.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s second-term priorities — the deficit, gun safety and immigration — may hinge on his ability to inject himself into negotiations to just the right degree.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The days ahead could be decisive ones for the main pieces of President Obama’s second-term agenda: long-range deficit reduction, gun safety and changes to immigration law.

articles.headline: Margaret Thatcher, ‘Iron Lady’ Who Set Britain on New Course, Dies at 87
articles.snippet: Mrs. Thatcher, who set her country on a rightward economic path, held her nation’s top office longer than any other British politician in the 20th century.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Thatcher, who set her country on a rightward economic path, held her nation’s top office longer than any other British politician in the 20th century.
articles.lead_paragraph: Margaret Thatcher, the “Iron Lady” of British politics, who set her country on a rightward economic course, led it to victory in the Falklands war and helped guide the United States and the Soviet Union through the cold war’s difficult last years, died on Monday in London. She was 87.

articles.headline: Thatcher’s Fiscal Policies Are Still a Tough Sell for Europe
articles.snippet: Margaret Thatcher’s conservative prescriptions for her country’s economy have never found fertile soil on the Continent, not even amid a gloom at least as dark as that of ’70s Britain.
articles.abstract: Margaret Thatcher’s conservative prescriptions for her country’s economy have never found fertile soil on the Continent, not even amid a gloom at least as dark as that of ’70s Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As word of Margaret Thatcher’s death spread on Monday, it seemed fitting that Prime Minister David Cameron was engaged in what had been billed as a European tour to bring the Continent around to her conservative way of thinking, particularly about Britain’s relationship with Europe.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Alan Cowell
